greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest k such that p(n)^5 - k is prime where p(n) is the n-th prime.
link: Harvey P. Dale, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
example: p(10)=29, 29^5 = 20511149; for odd k and n > 1, p(n)^r - k is even and thus not prime, so we only need consider even k.
for k = 4: 20511149 - 4 = 20511145, which is 5 * 4102229, also not prime.
for k = 6: 20511149 - 6 = 20511141, which is prime, so 6 is the smallest number that can be subtracted from 20511149 to make another prime.
results.author: _Carl R. White_, Sep 14 2007
